Read the passage. Then answer the questions below.
Loneliness is a universal emotion that most of us experience at least once during our lifetime, although certain events, such as an illness or a pandemic, can make it feel more pervasive. If you're currently experiencing feelings of loneliness, you aren't alone. In fact, a 2020 study by Cigna found that 61% of Americans reported being lonely in 2019, up from 54% in 2018. No matter what events are occurring around you, understanding- loneliness and its risks is important for recognizing when you may need support. Read on to learn what loneliness is, its causes, long-term risks and ways to cope with the emotions that may come up when you're lonely.
What Is Loneliness?
The American Psychological Association (APA) defines loneliness as the "affective and cognitive discomfort or uneasiness from being or perceiving oneself to be alone or being or perceiving to be or otherwise solitary." In other words, loneliness is the mental or emotional discomfort you may experience from either being alone or feeling as though you are alone. This feeling stems from your social needs not being met and/or an inability to get the social connection you desire.
Loneliness vs Being Alone
Although loneliness and being alone are commonly confused, being alone doesn't necessarily mean someone is lonely. "Loneliness is a feeling, while being alone is a situation or state of being, which is not inherently negative," says Nina Vasan, M.D., psychiatrist and professor at Stanford University School of Medicine and chief medical officer at Real, an online mental wellness membership site. "You can feel lonely even when you're surrounded by other people - such as a partner, family, co-workers or friends," continues Dr. Vasan. It's also possible to be alone, but not feel lonely, she adds. "For example, if you're by yourself but connecting to others through good communication or activities like volunteering, you don't feel lonely."

questions.uddipok:
Put the following parts of the story in correct order to rewrite the whole story.
(a) Mandela joined the African National Congress in 1942.
(b) In 1993, Mandela was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
(c) For 20 years, he directed a campaign of peaceful, non-violent defiance against the South African Government and its racist policies.
(d) Mandela died at his home in Johannesburg on December 5, 2013 at the age of 95.
(e) In 1993, South African President F.W. de Klerk was also awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
(f) In 2009, Mandela's birthday was declared "Mandela Day" to promote global peace.
(g) Nelson Mandela was born on July 18, 1918 in South Africa.
(h) In 1994, Mandela was elected as South Africa's first black President.

sub_questions.explanation:
Ans: g + a + c + b + e + h + f + d
Nelson Mandela was born on July 18, 1918 in South Africa. Mandela joined the African National Congress in 1942. For 20 years, he directed a campaign of peaceful, non-violent defiance against the South African Government and its racist policies. In 1993, Mandela was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. In 1993, South African President F.W. de Klerk was also awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. In 1994, Mandela was elected as South Africa's first black President. In 2009, Mandela's birthday was declared "Mandela Day" to promote global peace. Mandela died at his home in Johannesburg on December 5, 2013 at the age of 95.

sub_questions.explanation:
Perseverance is the Key to Success
Robert Bruce was the king of Scotland. His Army was defeated again and again against the King Edward-I of England. Being defeated for six times, he lost his hope. Gętting disappointed, he took shelter in a remote cave. Once, he was lying in the cave. Then he saw a spider trying hard to reach the ceiling of the cave. The spider failed again and again to suceeed. But he did not give up hope. Bruce saw the spider climbing to the ceiling after some unsuccessful attempts. This dauntless spider inspired Bruce to shake off the darkness of despair.. He gathered an army of strong men and attacked his enemies. The enemies courted defeat and Bruce regained his kingdom. It taught us that, ‘perseverance is the key to success'.

questions.uddipok: Write a dialogue between you and your friend Reefat about the reasons for the degradation of ethics and values in present-day society and suggest some ways to improve this condition.

sub_questions.explanation:
Myself : Good morning,
Reefat! How are you today?
Reefat: Good morning! I'm fine, thank you, What about you?
Myself: I'm doing well. Reefat, don't you think ethics and values are declining in our society nowadays?
Reefat: Yes, I feel the same. People are becoming more self-centered. It's weakening the moral standards of people.
Myself: True. Actually I think, people are ignoring honesty and respect because of the influence of social media and unhealthy competition.
Reefat: Exactly. Corruption in politics and business also sets a bad example for the younger generation. Myself: So, how can we improve this condition?
Reefat: Families. can play a stronger role in teaching children values from an early age.
Myself: And schools should include moral education and character-building lessons along with academic subjects.
Reefat: Media can also help by promoting positive role models. They should be more careful about highlighting any negative behavior.
Myself: Yes, and we must possess honesty, compassion, empathy, and sense of responsibility.
Reefat:If everyone contributes in their own way, society can gradually restore its lost ethics and values.
Myself: Well said, Reefat. Thank you for sharing your thoughts.
Reefat: Thank you too, Ruma. It was aninformative discussion, Goodbye, take care!
Myself : Goodbye,
Reefat. See you soon!
